thread.title: Garden Guru: Autumn Gardenfest celebrates cool season |

author: DispatchDaemon
title: Garden Guru: Autumn Gardenfest celebrates cool season |
text:
Photos Back | Next Norman Winter photo Cucurbit display along the Crapemyrtle Allee. Back | Next Norman Winter photo Pumpkins in the Mediterranean Garden. Back | Next Norman Winter photo Pumpkins contrasting wth Blue Agave leaves. Back | Next Pumpkins and Verbenas Back | Next Norman Winter photo Use pumpkins in your flower displays. Back | Next Norman Winter photo Nothing says fall like pumpkins and gourds. After the long, hot summer, you feel like celebrating fall’s arrival and there is no better way than with the use of pumpkins in your landscape decorating. The feeling of fall and festivals is in the air and one of the best ways to celebrate and get tips on decorating with pumpkins is to take a stroll through the Coastal Georgia Botanical Gardens on Oct. 23-24 at the Autumn Gardenfest.
You’ll get tips as you are strolling along the beautiful cucurbit displays seen in the Crape Myrtle Allee. You will want to be sure to stop for pictures here. Then walk on over and look at the pumpkins in the Mediterranean Garden, where they stand so picturesque against the giant blue agave and the Mexican bush sage in full bloom. Pay attention to the dozens of yellow sulphur butterflies flying all around as if they are celebrating the season.
The Autumn Gardenfest has been designed with the whole family in mind. On the Great Lawn behind the new Andrews Visitor and Education Center will be a children’s pumpkin maze, bounce house, story time at the water garden and a ride on the Bamboo Express.
On the lawn in front of the Pavilion you will find vendors selling plants. There will be those hard to find trees, roses, flowers, bulbs, daylilies, irises and, of course, pumpkins too. There will be food and refreshments making sure you’ll want to stay all day.
Actually you will want to partake both days of the festival as there is a once in a lifetime opportunity to hear some of the most well-known garden speakers in the country. The programs will be located in the Andrews Visitor and Education Center and begin at 1 p.m. on Friday.
Oct. 23
• 1 p.m. Joan Calder: Pollinators in the Garden — You Are Their Heroes
Conserving habitats for pollinators like bees and butterflies is not only critical but it can become a fun hobby that is sure to develop into a passion. Bees are responsible for one-third of the food we eat. Learn how to identify pollinators and the life cycle of butterflies, ladybugs, and native bees. We will look at not only the best plants but bee houses, how they work and how you can construct your own. Calder will also sign copies of her award-winning children’s book “Airplanes in the Garden Monarchs take Flight.”
• 2 p.m. Linda Askey: What Is Your Garden Style?
After 21 years with Southern Living, Linda knows a thing or two about style. It doesn’t matter if your garden grows symmetrical green bumps or features funky, found objects, it is your garden. Recognizing your own style helps create a garden that is cohesive and distinctive. If you are just starting out, the opportunities are endless, and that can be a blessing and a curse. If your garden is established, push through the inertia to recapture that thrill of something new. We’ll talk about the possibilities.
• 3 p.m. Norman Winter: Blooms, Birds & Butterflies
Norman Winter, director of the University of Georgia’s Coastal Georgia
Botanical Gardens and Savannah Morning News’ Garden Guru will show you how to have dazzling blooms that will bring in bees, butterflies and hummingbirds for a summer long season of excitement. You’ll learn the tricks in color combinations and texture too that will surely create that Kodak moment in your garden.
Oct. 24
• 9:30 a.m. Chris VanCleave, aka the Redneck Rosarian: Easy Care Roses for Lowcountry Gardens
Chris VanCleave is the creator of the Rose Chat Podcast that now has hundreds of thousands of listeners. He has also been a judge at the Biltmore Rose Trials the past two years. You will explore the how to’s of growing roses that will include a hands on rose care demo. He’ll show you rose options that will provide some wow in the garden with a minimum of care. He will be giving away special rose door prizes at the end of the talk.
• 10:30 a.m. Linda Askey: Bring Home a Little Wow
After 21 years with Southern Living, Askey knows that, simply put, “wow” is what we say when we trip over excellence in the garden. Whether it is a delight to the eye, unexpected humor or a tug on the heartstrings, garden surprises transform a garden walk into an experience, and therefore, a memory. Carefully composed plantings, over-achieving plants and creative garden ornament can each provide a “wow” moment. Askey will share some of her favorite “wows” from more than three decades of travel as a garden journalist with the hope of sending us home to create a little “wow” in our own gardens.
• 11:30 a.m. Diana Churchill: The Lowcountry’s Top Ten Winter Bird Celebrities
Diana Churchill, the Savannah Morning News’ Birder’s Eye View columnist, will be quick to tell you the Lowcountry is a treasure trove when it comes to birding. But are you missing the true celebrities that visit each year? Find out when these winged treasures will be making their annual visit, where you are most likely to see them and which ones you might entice to visit your backyard for a most enjoyable winter season of nature. She will also have a book signing of her book “Birder’s Eye View” after her presentation.
• 12:30 p.m. Norman Winter: Blooms, Birds & Butterflies
• 1:30 p.m. Joan Calder: Pollinators in the Garden - You Are Their Heroes
The Autumn Gardenfest is noon to 4 p.m. on Oct. 23 and 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. on Oct. 24. There is a $5 per car entry fee. For more information call 912-921-5460.
Norman Winter is the director of the Coastal Georgia Botanical Gardens at the Historic Bamboo Farm, University of Georgia Cooperative Extension.
By Norman Winter
